climbs.name: Three's a Crowd
climbs.fa: Dan Green with Gina and Spike

content.description: Start on Augustin's and move left after 1st bolt. Continue up passing three more bolts to Piton Crack's anchor.A #3 C4 can be placed near the top to protect the runout to the anchors
content.location: Leftward trending line that shares anchors with Piton Crack, and shares the start with left line of Augustin's Flake.See photos.

content.description: Climbs the south face of The Prow formation. Start five feet left of The Prow and climb corner to 2nd bolt, then follow up nice red face.
content.protection: Five bolts lead to dual chain anchors. Once toproped, the overhang between bolt five and chains causes minor rope drag without a runner.
content.location: This dihedral is the left (SW) next-door neighbor to The Prow route, nearly sharing an arête at the top. To approach, park at the shore of the Old Stagecoach Road (due N of the bridge, along the W side of the river) and briefly hike upstream (NE) (trail is well-traveled and visible), finding the first switchback (also well-beaten) to the base of the rock. This hike is likely not much more than 100 footsteps.

content.description: 'Stem It Black' is the obvious black corner toward the left side of Stagecoach Wall.  The rock is crumbly off the ground, but improves somewhat higher up.   As suggested, good stemming the whole way.
content.protection: Cams and nuts to 3".  At the top, reach right to the 2-bolt anchor for Pockets.
content.location: 'Stem It Black' is the black corner near the left end of Stagecoach Wall, between the two bolted arete climbs: The Prow  and Pockets.

content.description:
Start on detatched flake to palm-sized sloper. Bust left to big sidepull and move back middle to crux lone-finger pocket and balancey moves up to pockets. 

View down onto the Old Stagecoach crag left end.  Bolted lines include (L-R) The Prow, Pockets, Mama, Popay's Revolt
content.protection: 6 quickdraws for SS 3/8" Rawl bolts. Chain anchors with SS wire gates.

content.description: Various pockets in good stone to thin overhanging finish
content.protection: 7 Quickdraws for SS 3/8" bolts to sport chain anchor with SS wired gates.
content.location: To the Rio side of the Prow.

content.description: The bottom has a sporty move to the second bolt but the crux is thin edges to and above the 4th bolt.  (You can avoid this by climbing wide to right after clipping 3rd bolt. Po'Pay or Pope' was from Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo and planned the Pueblo Revolt of 1680 while in Taos pueblo, the only time the Spanish were driven from an entire region of the New World.  They returned with a vengeance 12 years later.
content.location: Bolted route right of Augustin's flake.

content.description: Climb up to the rectangular slot, clip the pins and sort out how to bring your feet up in order to reach the next good horizontal hold.  Easier from here to the top.
content.protection: Cams and nuts to 2".  Fixed pitons protect the crux moves.  A 2-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: This is a thin crack with a rectangular slot.  If you see the fixed pins, you're there.  It is just to the right of the new bolted climb Monkeywrenchin' Momma

content.description: #1 G, the leftmost sport climb on Stagecoach Wall, makes for a good first lead with fun moves off horizontal jugs and favorably spaced bolts.
content.location: This is the leftmost bolted climb on Stagecoach Wall.

content.description: Bouldery start to undercling then mantle to small ledge.  Finish on pocketed face.
content.protection: Bolts to chain back on rock.
content.location: Fourth bolted route from the left. Just left of 5.10 crack with pins.

content.description:
Forest's Face heads up and right on big blocks to reach a steeper crack (crux) at the top. 

  Not bad, in an area with few climbs at this grade.
content.location: Forest's Face climbs blocks and cracks to reach the next anchor right of Po'Pay's Revolt, which is the rightmost bolted climb on Stagecoach Wall.

content.description: Climb the face just right of The Prow. Crux is after the 3rd bolt. For full value, avoid using the crack or face to its right.
content.location: Bolted route on face immediately to the right of The Prow.

content.description: Cactus Karma takes on a fun and improbable steep hand crack near the right side of Stagecoach Wall.  Pulling through the crux is a great way to learn jams.  Difficulty eases near the top.   One of the best easier climbs on the cliff.
content.location: This is the steep hand-crack that is the 2nd climb from the right end of Stagecoach Wall.

content.description: Stem up the right-facing corner with the finger crack, or climb the flake to the right.  Tall people can stem between these two features.  The difficulty eases as the cracks widen up high.   You can climb only the left crack, or only the flake crack to make for more difficult challenges.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 3", to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: Augustin's Flake is the crack to the right of the crack with fixed pins; and just left of the rightmost bolted route Po'Pay's Revolt.   Faint inscription with the name 'Augustin' is at the base.

content.description:
The old westward bound stage crossing from the original John Dunn Bridge over the Rio Grande.  Massive stone walls and old roadbed bring you to the base of the crag just upstream and northwest of the rafters' put-in for the Upper Box. Short (40 ft) crag with 5.5 to 5.11 trad and sport routes.  Great Spring and Fall climbing with easy access (5 min approach). You can swim in the Rio if you are overheated or dip in the hotsprings if you're chilled. 

  See "Taos Rock Climbs & Boulders of Northern New Mexico" by Jay Foley, Sharp End Books, 2005. The only complete guide for the other climbs in this area. 

  The anchors for these climbs can be reached from the top.  Follow the old road up left and scramble along the top (careful to not knock rock down on your party). Some are pretty easy to rig (the sport routes).  Otherwise, look to sling trees at the top to reach them.
